thread.title: Big W becoming a basket case in the shopping ailses
thread.title_full: Big W becoming a basket case in the shopping ailses

author: Elizabeth Knight
title: Big W becoming a basket case in the shopping ailses
text:
Inside the banks' rubbery earnings reports 
Bloomberg Gadfly Columnist David Fickling reports on discrepancies in Australian banks' earnings reports. More videos Woolworths earnings report 
Supermarket chain Woolworths has beaten rival Coles in sales growth for the first time in over 7 years. 
The hot-shot retailer, Sally Macdonald, who had been employed to turn the business around left mysteriously in November after only a year in the job. She had a fix-it plan that Woolworths said would remain after she left but it now says the business will be the subject of a new strategic review - about which it would furnish no detail. 
Chairman Gordon Cairns has demonstrated a pretty clear appetite for radical solutions to problem brands and underperforming executives. Related Content Caltex pumps up retail to head off loss from Woolies fuel supply 
Woolworths has taken impairment charges against the value of Big W a couple of times leaving the business with a carrying value of $360 million and a note that this could be further written down depending on performance. 
But there was basically no commentary on what was going on inside Big W - whether its woes were the result of unpopular product or incorrect pricing. It noted the first in-house designed ranges in apparel and homewares had arrived and an interim boss had been put in place. Advertisement 
Its major competitor, the Wesfarmers-owned Kmart, on the other hand is wiping the floor with Big W. 
Target - which is also owned by Wesfarmers - is the ugly ducking of that group. Its earnings fell by $58 million to $16 million, with revenue down 17.7 per cent as the department store chain battles to revive its fortunes. SHARE Share on Twitter TWEET Link Woolworths chairman Gordon Cairns and CEO Brad Banducci. The company offered no commentary on Wednesday about Big W's performance. Photo: Jessica Hromas 
It has also been the subject of numerous strategic reviews and management changes. Kmart boss Guy Russo is now in charge but there are no signs yet on any financial improvement. 
The extent of the resolve of the two majors, Coles and Woolworths, to win the supermarket market share war could now start to worry investors. Their war chests are getting larger and their profits are falling. SHARE Share on Twitter Link Big W is now barely profitable with earnings falling around 89 per cent in the first half of the 2017 financial year. Photo: Brendan Esposito 
Woolworths scored a victory on Wednesday, beating Coles in the first half of financial year 2017 on the much-watched measure of sales growth. But it was a costly win. EBIT margins were shredded and profits went backwards. 
Wesfarmers' supermarket brand, Coles, also sustained a fall in profit as it ploughed money into lowering prices at the checkout - a strategy Woolworths has now been employing for more than a year. SHARE
